author: Authority control
cleaned_text: Shamanism or samanism is a religious practice that involves a practitioner (shaman or saman) interacting with the [spirit world](/wiki/Spirit_world_(Spiritualism)) of consciousness](/wiki/Altered_state_of_consciousness), such as [trance](/wiki/Trance). [[1]](#cite_note-:0-1) [[2]](#cite_note-2) The goal of this is usually to direct [spirits](/wiki/Non-physical_entity) or [spiritual energies](/wiki/Energy_(esotericism)) into the physical world for the purpose of healing, [divination](/wiki/Divination), or to aid human beings in some other way. [[1]](#cite_note-:0-1) Beliefs and practices categorized as "shamanic" have attracted the interest of scholars from a variety of disciplines, including anthropologists, archeologists, historians, religious studies scholars, philosophers and psychologists. Hundreds of books and [academic papers](/wiki/Academic_publishing#Scholarly_paper) on the subject have been produced, with a peer-reviewed academic journal being devoted to the study of shamanism. In the 20th century, non- [Indigenous](/wiki/Indigenous_Peoples) Westerners involved in countercultural movements, such as [hippies](/wiki/Hippie) and the [New Age](/wiki/New_Age) created modern magicoreligious practices influenced by their ideas of various [Indigenous religions](/wiki/Indigenous_religion), creating what has been termed [neoshamanism](/wiki/Neoshamanism) or the neoshamanic movement. [[3]](#cite_note-3) It has affected the development of many [neopagan](/wiki/Modern_Paganism) practices, as well as faced a backlash and accusations of [cultural appropriation](/wiki/Cultural_appropriation), [[4]](#cite_note-Waveland_Press-4) exploitation and misrepresentation when outside observers have tried to practice the ceremonies of, or represent, centuries-old cultures to which they do not belong. Etymology[ the [Russian](/wiki/Russian_language) word amán, which itself comes from the word samn from a [Tungusic language](/wiki/Tungusic_language) [[7]](#cite_note-7) - possibly from the southwestern dialect of the [Evenki](/wiki/Evenki_language) spoken by the Sym Evenki peoples, [[8]](#cite_note-8) or from the [Manchu language](/wiki/Manchu_language). [[9]](#cite_note-9) The etymology of the word is sometimes the Tungus root s-, connection on linguistic grounds: "The possibility cannot be completely rejected, but neither should it be accepted without reservation since the assumed derivational relationship is phonologically irregular (note especially the vowel quantities)." [[12]](#cite_note-12) [Mircea Eliade](/wiki/Mircea_Eliade) noted that the [Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit) word [ramaa](/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a), designating a wandering monastic or holy figure, has spread to many Central Asian languages along with [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism) and could be the ultimate origin of the word shaman. [[13]](#cite_note-13) The term was adopted by Russians interacting with the Indigenous peoples in [Siberia](/wiki/Siberia). It is found in the memoirs of the exiled Russian churchman [Avvakum](/wiki/Avvakum). [[14]](#cite_note-14) It was brought to Western Europe twenty years later by the Dutch traveler [Nicolaes Witsen](/wiki/Nicolaes_Witsen), who reported his stay and journeys among the Tungusic- and [Samoyedic](/wiki/Samoyedic_languages)-speaking [Indigenous peoples [Lübeck](/wiki/L%C3%BCbeck), published in 1698 his account of a Russian embassy to China; a translation of his book, published the same year, introduced the word shaman to English speakers. [[16]](#cite_note-16) Anthropologist and archeologist Silvia Tomaskova argued that by the mid-1600s, many Europeans applied the [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic_language) term [shaitan](/wiki/Shaitan) (meaning "devil") to the non-Christian practices and beliefs of Indigenous peoples beyond the [Ural Mountains](/wiki/Ural_Mountains). [[17]](#cite_note-17) She suggests that shaman may have entered the various Tungus dialects as a corruption of this term, and then been told to [Christian missionaries](/wiki/Christian_missionaries), explorers, soldiers and colonial administrators with whom the people had increasing contact for centuries. A female shaman is sometimes called a shamanka, which is not an actual Tungus term but simply shaman plus the Russian suffix [-ka](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/-%D0%BA%D0%B0#Russian) (for [feminine](/wiki/Grammatical_gender) nouns). [[18]](#cite_note-18) Definitions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=3)] There is no single agreed-upon definition for the word "shamanism" among anthropologists. Thomas Downson suggests three shared elements of shamanism: practitioners consistently alter consciousness, the community regards altering consciousness as an important ritual practice, and the knowledge about the practice is controlled. The English historian [Ronald Hutton](/wiki/Ronald_Hutton) noted that by the dawn of the 21st century, there were four separate definitions of the term which appeared to be in use: - The first of these uses the term to refer to "anybody who contacts a spirit world while in an altered state of consciousness". - The second definition limits the term to refer to those who contact a spirit world while in an altered state of consciousness at the behest of others. - The third definition attempts to distinguish shamans from other magicoreligious specialists who are believed to contact spirits, such as " [mediums](/wiki/Mediumship)", " [witch doctors](/wiki/Witch_doctor)", "spiritual healers" or "prophets," by claiming that shamans undertake some particular technique not used by the others. (Problematically, scholars advocating the third view have failed to agree on what the defining technique should be.) - The fourth definition identified by Hutton uses "shamanism" to refer to the [Indigenous religions](/wiki/Indigenous_religions)of Siberia and neighboring parts of Asia. [[20]](#cite_note-20)According to the Golomt Center for Shamanic Studies, a Mongolian organization of shamans, the Evenk word shaman would more accurately be translated as "priest". [[21]](#cite_note-21) According [[22]](#cite_note-OED-22) is someone who is regarded as having access to, and influence in, the world of [benevolent and malevolent spirits](/wiki/Evocation), who typically enters into a [trance](/wiki/Trance) state during a [ritual](/wiki/Ritual), and practices [divination](/wiki/Divination) and [healing](/wiki/Healing). [[1]](#cite_note-:0-1) [[22]](#cite_note-OED-22) According to Juha is attested to contradict the assumption that the meaning 'shaman' also derives from [Proto-Tungusic](/wiki/Tungusic_languages)" and may have roots that extend back in time at least two millennia. [[23]](#cite_note-23) The term was introduced to the west after Russian forces [conquered](/wiki/Siege_of_Kazan) the shamanistic [Khanate of Kazan](/wiki/Khanate_of_Kazan) in 1552. The term "shamanism" was first applied by [Western](/wiki/Western_world) anthropologists as outside observers of the ancient religion of the [Turks](/wiki/Turkic_peoples) and [Mongols](/wiki/Mongols), as well as those of the neighbouring Tungusic- and [Samoyedic](/wiki/Samoyedic_languages)-speaking peoples. Upon observing more religious traditions around the world, some Western anthropologists began to also use the term in a very broad sense. The term was used to describe unrelated magicoreligious practices found within the [ethnic religions](/wiki/Ethnic_religion) of other parts of Asia, Africa, Australasia and even completely unrelated parts of the Americas, as they believed these practices to be similar to one another. [[24]](#cite_note-24) While the term has been incorrectly applied by cultural outsiders to many Indigenous spiritual practices, the words "shaman" and "shamanism" do not accurately describe the variety and complexity that is Indigenous spirituality. Each nation and tribe has its own way of life, and uses terms in their own languages. [[25]](#cite_note-25) [Mircea Eliade](/wiki/Mircea_Eliade) writes, "A first definition of this complex phenomenon, and perhaps the least hazardous, will be: shamanism = 'technique of [religious ecstasy](/wiki/Religious_ecstasy)'." [[26]](#cite_note-Eli72-26) Shamanism encompasses the premise that shamans are intermediaries or messengers between the human world and the spirit worlds. Shamans are said to treat ailments and illnesses by mending the soul. Alleviating traumas affecting the soul or spirit are believed to restore the physical body of the individual to balance and wholeness. Shamans also claim to enter [supernatural realms](/wiki/Otherworld) or [dimensions](/wiki/Plane_(esotericism)) to obtain solutions to problems afflicting the community. Shamans claim to visit other worlds or dimensions to bring guidance to misguided souls and to ameliorate illnesses of the human soul caused by foreign elements. Shamans operate primarily within the spiritual world, which, they believe, in turn affects the human world. The restoration of balance is said to result in the elimination of the ailment. [[26]](#cite_note-Eli72-26) Criticism of the term[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=4)] The anthropologist [Alice Kehoe](/wiki/Alice_Kehoe) criticizes the term "shaman" in her book Shamans and Religion: An Anthropological Exploration in Critical Thinking. Part of this criticism involves the notion of [cultural appropriation](/wiki/Cultural_appropriation). [[4]](#cite_note-Waveland_Press-4) This includes criticism of [New Age](/wiki/New_Age) and modern Western forms of shamanism, which, according to Kehoe, misrepresent or dilute Indigenous practices. Kehoe also believes that the term reinforces racist ideas such as the [noble savage](/wiki/Noble_savage). Kehoe is highly critical of [Mircea Eliade](/wiki/Mircea_Eliade)'s work on shamanism as an invention synthesized from various sources unsupported by more direct research. To Kehoe, citing that ritualistic practices (most notably drumming, trance, chanting, entheogens and hallucinogens, spirit communication and healing) as being definitive of shamanism is poor practice. Such citations ignore the fact that those practices exist outside of what is defined as shamanism and play similar roles even in nonshamanic cultures (such as the role of chanting in rituals in [Abrahamic religions](/wiki/Abrahamic_religions)) and that in their expression are unique to each culture that uses them. Such practices cannot be generalized easily, accurately, or usefully into a global religion of shamanism. Because of this, Kehoe is also highly critical of the hypothesis that shamanism is an ancient, unchanged, and surviving religion from the Paleolithic period. [[4]](#cite_note-Waveland_Press-4) The term has been criticized[ [by whom?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions)] for its perceived colonial roots, and as a tool to perpetuate perceived contemporary linguistic colonialism. By Western scholars, the term "shamanism" is used to refer to a variety of different cultures and practices around the world, which can vary dramatically and may not be accurately represented by a single concept. Billy-Ray Belcourt, an author and award-winning scholar from the Driftpile Cree Nation in Canada, argues that using language with the intention of simplifying culture that is diverse, such as Shamanism, as it is prevalent in communities around the world and is made up of many complex components, works to conceal the complexities of the social and political violence that Indigenous communities have experienced at the hands of settlers. [[27]](#cite_note-Fatal_Naming_Rituals-27) Belcourt argues that language used to imply "simplicity" in regards to Indigenous culture, is a tool used to belittle Indigenous cultures, as it views Indigenous communities solely as a result of a history embroiled in violence, that leaves Indigenous communities only capable of simplicity and plainness. Anthropologist [Mihály Hoppál](/w/index.php?title=Mih%C3%A1ly_Hopp%C3%A1l&action=edit&redlink=1) also discusses whether the term "shamanism" is appropriate. He notes that for many readers, "-ism" implies a particular dogma, like Buddhism or Judaism. He recommends using the term "shamanhood" [[28]](#cite_note-summer-28) or "shamanship" [[29]](#cite_note-29) (a term used in old Russian and German [ethnographic](/wiki/Ethnography) reports at the beginning of the 20th century) for stressing the diversity and the specific features of the discussed cultures. He believes that this places more stress on the local variations [[10]](#cite_note-cogmap-10) and emphasizes that shamanism is not a religion of sacred [dogmas](/wiki/Dogma), but linked to the everyday life in a practical way. [[30]](#cite_note-30) Following similar thoughts, he also conjectures a contemporary paradigm shift. [[28]](#cite_note-summer-28) [Piers Vitebsky](/wiki/Piers_Vitebsky) also mentions that, despite really astonishing similarities, there is no unity in shamanism. The various, fragmented shamanistic practices and beliefs coexist with other beliefs everywhere. There is no record of pure shamanistic societies (although their existence is not impossible). [[31]](#cite_note-31) Norwegian social anthropologist Hakan Rydving has likewise argued for the abandonment of the "shaman" and "shamanism" as "scientific illusions." [[32]](#cite_note-32) Dulam Bumochir has affirmed the above critiques of "shamanism" as a Western construct created for comparative purposes and, in an extensive article, has documented the role of Mongols themselves, particularly "the partnership of scholars and shamans in the reconstruction of shamanism" in post-1990/post-communist Mongolia. [[33]](#cite_note-:3-33) This process has also been documented by Swiss anthropologist Judith Hangartner in her landmark study of Darhad shamans in Mongolia. [[34]](#cite_note-34) Historian Karena Kollmar-Polenz argues that the social construction and reification of shamanism as a religious "other" actually began with the 18th-century writings of Tibetan Buddhist monks in Mongolia and later "probably influenced the formation of European discourse on Shamanism". [[35]](#cite_note-The_Invention_of_Shamanism_in_18t-35) History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=5)] Shamanism is a system of religious practice. [[36]](#cite_note-:1-36) Historically, it is often associated with [Indigenous](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples) and [tribal societies](/wiki/Tribal_societies), and involves belief that shamans, with a connection to the [otherworld](/wiki/Otherworld), have the power to heal the sick, communicate with spirits, and escort souls of the dead to the [afterlife](/wiki/Afterlife). The origins of Shamanism stem from indigenous peoples of far northern Europe and Siberia. [[37]](#cite_note-37) Despite structural implications of colonialism and imperialism that have limited the ability of Indigenous peoples to practice traditional spiritualities, many communities are undergoing resurgence through self-determination [[38]](#cite_note-38) and the reclamation of dynamic traditions. [[39]](#cite_note-39) Other groups have been able to avoid some of these structural impediments by virtue of their isolation, such as the nomadic [Tuvan](/wiki/Tuvans) (with an estimated population of 3000 people surviving from this tribe). [[40]](#cite_note-:4-40) Tuva is one of the most isolated Asiatic tribes in Russia where the art of shamanism has been preserved until today due to its isolated existence, allowing it to be free from the influences of other major religions. [[41]](#cite_note-41) Beliefs[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=6)] There are many variations of shamanism throughout the world, but several common beliefs are shared by all forms of shamanism. Common beliefs identified by [Eliade](/wiki/Mircea_Eliade) (1972) [[26]](#cite_note-Eli72-26) are the following: - Spirits exist and they play important roles both in individual lives and in human society - The shaman can communicate with the spirit world - Spirits can be benevolent or malevolent - The shaman can treat sickness caused by malevolent spirits - The shaman can employ [trances](/wiki/Trance)inducing techniques to incite visionary ecstasy and go on [vision quests](/wiki/Vision_quest) - The shaman's spirit can leave the body to enter the [supernatural](/wiki/Supernatural)world to search for answers - The shaman evokes animal images as [spirit guides](/wiki/Spirit_guides), [omens](/wiki/Omen), and message-bearers - The shaman can perform other varied forms of [divination](/wiki/Divination), [scry](/wiki/Scry), throw bones or [runes](/wiki/Runes), and sometimes foretell of future events As Alice Kehoe [[4]](#cite_note-Waveland_Press-4) notes, Eliade's conceptualization of shamans produces a universalist image of Indigenous cultures, which perpetuates notions of the dead (or dying) Indian [[42]](#cite_note-42) as well as the noble savage. [[43]](#cite_note-43) Shamanism is based on the premise that the visible world is pervaded by invisible forces or spirits which affect the lives of the living. [[44]](#cite_note-Peru-44) Although the causes of disease lie in the spiritual realm, inspired by malicious spirits, both spiritual and physical methods are used to heal. Commonly, a shaman "enters the body" of the patient to confront the spiritual infirmity and heals by banishing the infectious spirit. Many shamans have expert knowledge of medicinal plants native to their area, and an herbal treatment is often prescribed. In many places shamans learn directly from the plants, harnessing their effects and healing properties, after obtaining permission from the indwelling or patron spirits. In the Peruvian Amazon Basin, shamans and [curanderos](/wiki/Curandero) use medicine songs called [icaros](/wiki/Icaro) to evoke spirits. Before a spirit can be summoned it must teach the shaman its song. [[44]](#cite_note-Peru-44) The use of [totemic](/wiki/Totem) items such as rocks with special powers and an [animating spirit](/wiki/Animism) is common. Such practices are presumably very ancient. [Plato](/wiki/Plato) wrote in his [Phaedrus](/wiki/Phaedrus_(dialogue)) that the "first prophecies were the words of an oak", and that those who lived at that time found it rewarding enough to "listen to an oak or a stone, so long as it was telling the truth". Belief in witchcraft and sorcery, known as [brujería](/wiki/Brujer%C3%ADa) in Latin America, exists in many societies. Other societies assert all shamans have the power to both cure and kill. Those with shamanic knowledge usually enjoy great power and prestige in the community, but they may also be regarded suspiciously or fearfully as potentially harmful to others. [[45]](#cite_note-45) By engaging in their work, a shaman is exposed to significant personal risk as shamanic plant materials can be toxic or fatal if misused. [Spells](/wiki/Spell_(paranormal)) are commonly used in an attempt to protect against these dangers, and the use of more dangerous plants is often very highly ritualized. Soul and spirit concepts[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=7)] - Healing [Healing](/wiki/Healing)may be based closely on the soul concepts of the belief system of the people served by the shaman. [[49]](#cite_note-sem-shamheal-49)It may consist of the supposed retrieving the lost soul of the ill person. [[50]](#cite_note-resoul-50) - Scarcity of hunted game [Scarcity](/wiki/Scarcity)of hunted game can be solved by "releasing" the souls of the animals from their hidden abodes. Besides that, many [taboos](/wiki/Taboo)may prescribe the behavior of people towards game, so that the souls of the animals do not feel angry or hurt, or the pleased soul of the already killed prey can tell the other, still living animals, that they can allow themselves to be caught and killed. [[51]](#cite_note-51) [[52]](#cite_note-Gab-KarEszk-52) - Infertility of women [Infertility](/wiki/Infertility)of women is thought to be cured by obtaining the soul of the expected child[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] - Spirits - Spirits are invisible entities that only shamans can see. They are seen as persons that can assume a human or animal body. [[53]](#cite_note-:2-53)Some animals in their physical forms are also seen as spirits such as the case of the [eagle](/wiki/Eagle), [snake](/wiki/Snake), [jaguar](/wiki/Jaguar), and [rat](/wiki/Rat). [[53]](#cite_note-:2-53)Beliefs related to spirits can explain many different phenomena. [[54]](#cite_note-54)For example, the importance of storytelling, or acting as a singer, can be understood better if the whole belief system is examined. A person who can memorize long texts or songs, and play an instrument, may be regarded as the beneficiary of contact with the spirits (e.g. [Khanty](/wiki/Khanty)people). [[55]](#cite_note-singtellplay-55) Practice[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=8)] Generally, enter the "spirit world" by effecting a transition of consciousness, entering into an [ecstatic](/wiki/Religious_ecstasy) trance, either [autohypnotically](/wiki/Autosuggestion) or through the use of [entheogens](/wiki/Entheogen) or ritual performances. [[56]](#cite_note-56) [[57]](#cite_note-57) The methods employed are diverse, and are often used together. Music and songs[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=9)] Just like shamanism itself, [[10]](#cite_note-cogmap-10) music and songs related to it in various cultures are diverse. In several instances, songs related to shamanism are intended to imitate [natural sounds](/wiki/Natural_sounds), via [onomatopoeia](/wiki/Onomatopoeia). [[58]](#cite_note-onom-58) [Sound mimesis in various cultures](/wiki/Sound_mimesis_in_various_cultures) may serve other functions not necessarily related to shamanism: practical goals such as luring game in the hunt; [[59]](#cite_note-natt-59) or entertainment learning[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=10)] Shamans often claim to have been called through dreams or signs. However, some say their powers are inherited. In traditional societies shamanic training varies in length, but generally takes years. Turner and colleagues [[61]](#cite_note-61) mention a phenomenon called "shamanistic initiatory crisis", a [rite of passage](/wiki/Rite_of_passage) for shamans-to-be, commonly involving physical illness or psychological crisis. The significant role of initiatory illnesses in the calling of a shaman can be found in the case history of [Chuonnasuan](/wiki/Oroqen_people#Religion), who was one of the last shamans among the Tungus peoples in [Northeast China](/wiki/Northeast_China). healer](/wiki/Wounded_healer) is an [archetype](/wiki/Archetype) for a shamanic trial and journey. This process is important to young shamans. They undergo a type of sickness that pushes them to the brink of death. This is said to happen for two reasons: - The shaman crosses over to the underworld. This happens so the shaman can venture to its depths to bring back vital information for the sick and the tribe. - The shaman must become sick to understand sickness. When the shaman overcomes their own sickness, they believe that they will hold the cure to heal all that suffer. [[63]](#cite_note-63) Other practices[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=11)] Items used in spiritual practice[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=12)] Shamans may employ varying materials in spiritual practice in different cultures. - Drums - The [drum](/wiki/Drum)is used by shamans of several peoples in Siberia. [[64]](#cite_note-64) [[65]](#cite_note-65)The beating of the drum allows the shaman to achieve an altered state of consciousness or to travel on a journey between the physical and spiritual worlds. Much fascination surrounds the role that the acoustics of the drum play to the shaman. Shaman drums are generally constructed of an animal-skin stretched over a bent wooden hoop, with a handle across the hoop. Roles[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=13)] Shamans have been conceptualized as those who are able to gain knowledge and power to heal in the [spiritual world](/wiki/Spirit_world_(Spiritualism)) or dimension. Most shamans have dreams or [visions](/wiki/Vision_(spirituality)) that convey certain messages. Shamans may claim to have or have acquired many [spirit guides](/wiki/Spirit_guides), who they believe guide and direct them in their travels in the spirit world. These spirit guides are always thought to be present within the shaman, although others are said to encounter them only when the shaman is in a [trance](/wiki/Trance). The spirit guide energizes the shamans, enabling them to enter the spiritual dimension. Shamans claim to heal within the communities and the spiritual dimension by returning lost parts of the human soul from wherever they have gone. Shamans also claim to cleanse excess negative energies, which are said to confuse or pollute the soul. Shamans act as [mediators](/wiki/Mediation) in their cultures. [[67]](#cite_note-mediator-67) [[68]](#cite_note-mediator2-68) Shamans claim to communicate with the spirits on behalf of the community, including the spirits of the deceased. Shamans believe they can communicate with both living and dead to alleviate unrest, unsettled issues, and to deliver gifts to the spirits. Among the [Selkups](/wiki/Selkup_people), the [sea duck](/wiki/Merginae) is a spirit animal. Ducks fly in the air and dive in the water and are thus believed to belong to both the upper world and the world below. [[69]](#cite_note-Hoppal_a-69) Among other Siberian peoples, these characteristics are attributed to waterfowl in general. [[70]](#cite_note-70) The upper world is the afterlife primarily associated with deceased humans and is believed to be accessed by soul journeying through a portal in the sky. The lower world or "world below" is the afterlife primarily associated with animals and is believed to be accessed by soul journeying through a portal in the earth. [[71]](#cite_note-71) In shamanic cultures, many animals are regarded as spirit animals. Shamans perform a variety of functions depending upon their respective cultures; [[72]](#cite_note-multfunc-72) healing, [[49]](#cite_note-sem-shamheal-49) [[73]](#cite_note-73) leading a [sacrifice](/wiki/Sacrifice), by storytelling and songs, [[75]](#cite_note-memory-75) [fortune-telling](/wiki/Fortune-telling), and acting as a [psychopomp](/wiki/Psychopomp) ("guide of souls"). [[77]](#cite_note-psychopomp-77) A single shaman may fulfill several of these functions. [[72]](#cite_note-multfunc-72) The responsibilities of a shaman may include either guiding to their proper abode the souls of the dead (which may be guided either one-at-a-time or in a group, depending on the culture), and the curing of ailments. The ailments may be either purely physical afflictions—such as disease, which are claimed to be cured by gifting, flattering, threatening, or wrestling the disease-spirit (sometimes trying all these, sequentially), and which may be completed by displaying a supposedly extracted token of the disease-spirit (displaying this, even if "fraudulent", is supposed to impress the disease-spirit that it has been, or is in the process of being, defeated so that it will retreat and stay out of the patient's body), or else mental (including psychosomatic) afflictions—such as persistent terror, which is likewise believed to be cured by similar methods. In most languages a different term other than the one translated "shaman" is usually applied to a religious official leading sacrificial rites ("priest"), or to a raconteur ("sage") of traditional lore; there may be more of an overlap in functions (with that of a shaman), however, in the case of an interpreter of omens or of dreams. There are distinct types of shamans who perform more specialized functions. For example, among the [Nani people](/wiki/Nani_people), a distinct kind of shaman acts as a psychopomp. [[78]](#cite_note-78) Other specialized shamans may be distinguished according to the type of spirits, or realms of the spirit world, with which the shaman most commonly interacts. These roles vary among the [Nenets](/wiki/Nenets_people), [Enets](/wiki/Enets_people), and jardalanin, or "second spirit") knows many things about the associated beliefs. He or she accompanies the rituals and interprets the behaviors of the shaman. [[81]](#cite_note-Guan_Kouni-81) Despite these functions, the jardalanin is not a shaman. For this interpretative assistant, it would be unwelcome to fall into a trance. [[82]](#cite_note-interpreter-82) Ecological aspect[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=14)] Among the [Tucano people](/wiki/Tucano_people), a sophisticated system exists for [environmental resources management](/wiki/Environmental_resource_management) and for avoiding resource depletion through overhunting. This system is conceptualized mythologically and symbolically by the belief that breaking hunting restrictions may cause illness. As the primary teacher of tribal symbolism, the shaman may have a leading role in this [ecological](/wiki/Ecology) management, actively restricting hunting and fishing. The shaman is able to "release" game animals, or their souls, from their hidden abodes. [[83]](#cite_note-eco-83) [[84]](#cite_note-84) The [Piaroa people](/wiki/Piaroa_people) have ecological [[85]](#cite_note-ecopia-85) Among the [Inuit](/wiki/Inuit) the [angakkuq](/wiki/Angakkuq) (shamans) fetch the souls of game from remote places, [[86]](#cite_note-86) [[87]](#cite_note-87) or [soul travel](/wiki/Astral_projection) to ask for [Sea Woman](/wiki/Sedna_(mythology)). [[88]](#cite_note-88) Economics[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=15)] The way shamans get sustenance and take part in everyday life varies across cultures. In many Inuit groups, they provide services for the community and get a "due payment",[ [who?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions)] and believe the payment is given to the helping spirits. [[89]](#cite_note-mshare-89) An account states that the gifts and payments that a shaman receives are given by his partner spirit. Since it obliges the shaman to use his gift and to work regularly in this capacity, the spirit rewards him with the goods that it receives. [[90]](#cite_note-90) These goods, however, are only "welcome addenda". They are not enough to enable a full-time shaman. Shamans live like any other member of the group, as a hunter or housewife. Due to the popularity of [ayahuasca tourism](/wiki/Ayahuasca) in South America, there are practitioners in areas frequented by backpackers who make a living from leading ceremonies. [[91]](#cite_note-failed-shaman-91) [[89]](#cite_note-mshare-89) Academic study[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=16)] Cognitive and evolutionary approaches[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=17)] There are two major frameworks among cognitive and evolutionary scientists for explaining shamanism. The first, proposed by anthropologist Michael Winkelman, is known as the "neurotheological theory". [[92]](#cite_note-92) [[93]](#cite_note-93) According to Winkelman, shamanism develops reliably in human societies because it provides valuable benefits to the practitioner, their group, and individual clients. In particular, the trance states induced by dancing, hallucinogens, and other triggers are hypothesized to have an "integrative" effect on cognition, allowing communication among mental systems that specialize in [theory of mind](/wiki/Theory_of_mind), social intelligence, and natural history. [[94]](#cite_note-94) With this cognitive integration, the shaman can better predict the movement of animals, resolve group conflicts, plan migrations, and provide other useful services. The neurotheological theory contrasts with the "by-product" or "subjective" model of shamanism developed by Harvard anthropologist Manvir Singh. [[1]](#cite_note-:0-1) [[95]](#cite_note-95) [[96]](#cite_note-96) According to Singh, shamanism is a cultural technology that adapts to (or hacks) our psychological biases to convince us that a specialist can influence important but uncontrollable outcomes. [[97]](#cite_note-97) Citing work on [the psychology of magic and superstition](/wiki/Superstition#Superstition_and_psychology), Singh argues that humans search for ways of influencing uncertain events, such as healing illness, controlling rain, or attracting animals. As specialists compete to help their clients control these outcomes, they drive the evolution of psychologically compelling magic, producing traditions adapted to people's cognitive biases. Shamanism, Singh argues, is the culmination of this cultural evolutionary process—a psychologically appealing method for controlling uncertainty. For example, some shamanic practices exploit our intuitions about humanness: Practitioners use trance and dramatic initiations to seemingly become entities distinct from normal humans and thus more apparently capable of interacting with the invisible forces believed to oversee important outcomes. Influential cognitive and anthropological scientists such as [Pascal Boyer](/wiki/Pascal_Boyer) and [Nicholas Humphrey](/wiki/Nicholas_Humphrey) have endorsed Singh's approach, [[98]](#cite_note-98) although other researchers have criticized Singh's dismissal of individual- and group-level benefits. [[100]](#cite_note-100) David Lewis-Williams explains the origins of shamanic practice, and some of its precise forms, through aspects of human consciousness evinced in cave art and LSD experiments alike. [[101]](#cite_note-101) Ecological approaches and systems theory[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=18)] [Gerardo Reichel-Dolmatoff](/wiki/Gerardo_Reichel-Dolmatoff) relates these concepts to developments in the ways that modern science (systems theory, ecology, new approaches in anthropology and archeology) treats [causality](/wiki/Causality) in a less linear fashion. [[83]](#cite_note-eco-83) He also suggests a cooperation of modern science and Indigenous lore. [[102]](#cite_note-coop-102) Historical origins[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=19)] Shamanic practices may originate as early as the [Paleolithic](/wiki/Paleolithic), predating all organized religions, [[103]](#cite_note-103) [[104]](#cite_note-Narr-104) and certainly as early as the [Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic) period. [[104]](#cite_note-Narr-104) The earliest known undisputed burial of a shaman (and by extension the earliest undisputed evidence of shamans and shamanic practices) dates back to the early [Upper Paleolithic era](/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic) (c. 30,000 BP) in what is now the Czech Republic. [[105]](#cite_note-105) Sanskrit scholar and comparative mythologist [Michael Witzel](/wiki/Michael_Witzel) proposes that all of the world's mythologies, and also the concepts and practices of shamans, can be traced to the migrations of two prehistoric populations: the " [Gondwana](/wiki/Gondwana)" type (of circa 65,000 years ago) and the " [Laurasian](/wiki/Laurasia)" type (of circa 40,000 years ago). [[106]](#cite_note-106) In November 2008, researchers from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem announced the discovery of a 12,000-year-old site in [Israel](/wiki/Pre-history_of_the_Southern_Levant) that is perceived as one of the earliest-known shaman burials. The elderly woman had been arranged on her side, with her legs apart and folded inward at the knee. Ten large stones were placed on the head, pelvis, and arms. Among her unusual [grave goods](/wiki/Grave_goods) were 50 complete tortoise shells, a human foot, and certain body parts from animals such as a cow tail and eagle wings. Other animal remains came from a boar, leopard, and two martens. "It seems that the woman ... was perceived as being in a close relationship with these animal spirits", researchers noted. The grave was one of at least 28 graves at the site, located in a cave in lower [Galilee](/wiki/Galilee) and belonging to the [Natufian culture](/wiki/Natufian_culture), but is said to be unlike any other among the Epipaleolithic Natufians or in the Paleolithic "one who knows", [[11]](#cite_note-Diószegi_1962:13-11) [[108]](#cite_note-Hoppál_2005:14-108) implying, among other things, that the shaman is an expert in keeping together the multiple [codes](/wiki/Code) of the society, and that to be effective, shamans must maintain a comprehensive view in their mind which gives them certainty of [knowledge](/wiki/Knowledge). [[10]](#cite_note-cogmap-10) According to this view, the shaman uses (and the audience understands) multiple codes, expressing meanings in many ways: verbally, musically, artistically, and in dance. Meanings may be manifested in objects such as [amulets](/wiki/Amulet). [[108]](#cite_note-Hoppál_2005:14-108) If the shaman knows the culture of their community well, [[68]](#cite_note-mediator2-68) [[109]](#cite_note-109) [[110]](#cite_note-knowncult-110) and acts accordingly, their audience will know the used symbols and meanings and therefore trust the shamanic worker. [[110]](#cite_note-knowncult-110) [[111]](#cite_note-etym2-111) There are also [semiotic](/wiki/Semiotics), theoretical [[113]](#cite_note-113) [[114]](#cite_note-114) and examples of "mutually opposing symbols" in academic studies of Siberian lore, distinguishing a "white" shaman who contacts sky spirits for good aims by day, from a "black" shaman who contacts evil spirits for bad aims by night. [[115]](#cite_note-semiotics_of_shamanism-115) (Series of such opposing symbols referred to a world-view behind them. Analogously to the way grammar arranges words to express meanings and convey a world, also this formed a cognitive map). [[10]](#cite_note-cogmap-10) [[116]](#cite_note-hop-natworsib-116) Shaman's lore is rooted in the folklore of the community, which provides a "mythological mental map". [[117]](#cite_note-117) "ethnohermeneutics", [[116]](#cite_note-hop-natworsib-116) interpretation. Hoppál extended the term to include not only the interpretation of oral and written texts, but that of "visual texts as well (including motions, gestures and more complex rituals, and ceremonies performed, for instance, by shamans)". [[121]](#cite_note-ethnohermeneutics-121) Revealing the [animistic](/wiki/Animism) views in shamanism, but also their relevance to the contemporary world, where ecological problems have validated paradigms of balance and protection. [[118]](#cite_note-Hoppál_2007c_25-118) Decline and revitalization and tradition-preserving movements[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Shamanism&action=edit§ion=21)] Traditional, Indigenous shamanism is believed to be declining around the world. Whalers who frequently interacted with Inuit groups are one source of this decline in that region. [[122]](#cite_note-122) In many areas, former shamans ceased to fulfill the functions in the community they used to, as they felt mocked by their own community, [[125]](#cite_note-125) or regarded their own past as deprecated and were unwilling to talk about it to ethnographers. [[126]](#cite_note-shamed-126) Besides personal communications of former shamans, folklore texts may narrate directly about a deterioration process. For example, a [Buryat](/wiki/Buryats) epic text details the wonderful deeds of the ancient "first shaman" Kara-Gürgän: [[127]](#cite_note-Kara-Gurgan-127) he could even compete with God, create life, steal back the soul of the sick from God without his consent. A subsequent text laments that shamans of older times were stronger, possessing capabilities like omnividence, [[128]](#cite_note-flatland-128) fortune-telling even for decades in the future, moving as fast as a bullet. [[129]](#cite_note-deter-129) In most affected areas, shamanic practices ceased to exist, with authentic shamans dying and their personal experiences dying with them. The loss of memories is not always lessened by the fact the shaman is not always the only person in a community who knows the beliefs and motives related to the local shaman-hood. [[81]](#cite_note-Guan_Kouni-81) [[82]](#cite_note-interpreter-82) Although the shaman is often believed and trusted precisely because they "accommodate" to the beliefs of the community, [[110]](#cite_note-knowncult-110) several parts of the knowledge related to the local shamanhood consist of personal experiences of the shaman, or root in their family life, [[130]](#cite_note-drum-symbols-130) thus, those are lost with their death. Besides that, in many cultures, the entire traditional belief system has become endangered (often together with a partial or total [language shift](/wiki/Language_shift)), with the other people of the community remembering the associated beliefs and practices (or the language at all) grew old or died, many folklore memories songs, and texts were forgotten—which may threaten even such peoples who could preserve their isolation until the middle of the 20th century, like the [Nganasan](/wiki/Nganasan_people). [[131]](#cite_note-131) Some areas could enjoy a prolonged resistance due to their remoteness. - Variants of [shamanism among Inuit](/wiki/Inuit_religion)were once a widespread (and very diverse) phenomenon, but today is rarely practiced, as well as already having been in decline among many groups, even while the first major ethnological research was being done, [[132]](#cite_note-132)e.g. among Inuit, at the end of the 19th century, Sagloq, the last [angakkuq](/wiki/Angakkuq)who was believed to be able to travel to the sky and under the sea died—and many other former shamanic capacities were lost during that time as well, like ventriloquism and sleight of hand. [[133]](#cite_note-133) - The isolated location of Nganasan people allowed shamanism to be a living phenomenon among them even at the beginning of the 20th century, [[134]](#cite_note-hop-134)the last notable Nganasan shaman's ceremonies were recorded on film in the 1970s. [[135]](#cite_note-Hoppal-135) After exemplifying the general decline even in the most remote areas, there are revitalizations or tradition-preserving efforts as a response. Besides collecting the memories, [[136]](#cite_note-collect-136) there are also tradition-preserving [[137]](#cite_note-137) and even revitalization efforts, [[138]](#cite_note-138) led by authentic former shamans (for example among the Sakha people [[139]](#cite_note-authentic-revitalization-sakha-139) and Tuvans). [[124]](#cite_note-authentic-revitalization-tuva-124) [Native Americans in the United States](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States) do not call their traditional spiritual ways "shamanism". However, according to Richard L. Allen, research and policy analyst for the [Cherokee Nation](/wiki/Cherokee_Nation), they are regularly overwhelmed with inquiries by and about [fraudulent shamans](/wiki/Plastic_shaman), aka ("plastic medicine people"). [[140]](#cite_note-140) He adds, "One may assume that anyone claiming to be a Cherokee 'shaman, spiritual healer, or pipe-carrier', is equivalent to a modern day medicine show and snake-oil vendor." [[141]](#cite_note-RG-141) There are also [neoshamanistic](/wiki/Neoshamanism) movements, which usually differ from traditional shamanistic practice and beliefs in significant ways, and often have more connection to the [New Age](/wiki/New_Age) communities than traditional 20, 2020. Shamanism, religious phenomenon centred on the shaman, a person believed to achieve various powers through trance or ecstatic religious experience. Although shamans' repertoires vary from one culture to the next, they are typically thought to have the ability to heal the sick, to communicate with the otherworld, and often to escort the souls of the dead to that otherworld.
